title: Seneca Falls Convention
topic: suffrage
description: First women's rights convention
notes: Somewhat inspired by World Anti-Slavery Convention's (1840) exclusion of women, and the Anti-Slavery Convention of American Women (1837)

title: National Women's Rights Convention
topic: suffrage
description: First National Women's Rights Convention

title: The Provincial Freeman newspaper launches
topic: abolitionism, racism, discrimination, temperance,
description: First newspaper published by African-American woman, and Canada's first by any non-white woman.

title: American Equal Rights Association (AERA)
topic: suffrage
description: to secure Equal Rights to all American citizens, especially the right of suffrage, irrespective of race, color or sex
notes: Included both men and women

title: Working Women's Association (WWA)
topic: labor rights
description: response to exclusion of women in workers unions (specifically in printing and sewing trades)

title: National Woman Suffrage Association (NWSA)
topic: suffrage, gender equality
description: Divide over 15th Amendment, merged with American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA) to form National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA)
notes: All-female

title: American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA)
topic: suffrage
description: See above
notes: Included both men and women

title: Woman's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU)
topic: suffrage, temperance, protection of women and children, age of consent, violence, health, poverty
description: Has many affiliates across the world working for similar purposes. Not mainly focused on suffrage, but supports suffrage still, especially as it leads to reform in temperance and thus other areas (according to their theories).

title: Minor v. Happersett Case
topic: suffrage
description: The Supreme Court rules in Minor v. Happersett that the 14th Amendment does not guarantee women the right to vote. Citizenship does not give women voting rights, and women’s political rights are under individual states’ jurisdictions
notes: She tried to register to vote and was refused

title: Amendment for Women's Suffrage
topic: suffrage
description: prohibits the United States and its states from denying the right to vote to citizens of the United States on the basis of sex, in effect recognising the right of women to a vote
notes: Introduced in 1878, certified in 1920 as the 19th Amendment

title: First International Congress of Women held
notes: Suffrage deliberately avoided as there were many divided opinions about it, instead focused on other topics (including controversial ones)

title: Women's Christian Temperance Union New Zealand (WTCU NZ)
topic: suffrage, temperance, protection of women and children, age of consent
description: Organized many petition campaigns for women's suffrage.

title: Contagious Diseases Act Repealed
description: Acts which enforced compulsory examination of women and locked them away if they were found to have veneral diseases. Men were not examined.

title: Women's Suffrage League
figures: Rose Scott, Edward Charles Stirling, Mary Lee, Hector McLennan, Rose Birks, Mary Colton, Catherine Helen Spence
topic: suffrage, temperance, women's rights, protection of women and children, age of consent
description: ...campaigned for fairer treatment of women by the law, and greater legal protection for young women
notes: ...first meeting was held on 20 July 1888...

title: National American Woman Suffrage Association (NAWSA)
topic: suffrage
description: Pivotal role in passing 19th Amendment
notes: Membership went from 7k to 2mil

title: Electoral Bill containing provision for women’s suffrage in NZ passed
topic: suffrage
description: the first self-governing country in the world in which all adult women in New Zealand (with some exceptions, notably 'aliens' and inmates of prisons and asylums) had the right to vote in parliamentary elections
notes: Nearly 32,000 signatures on petition from 1893. Suffragettes gave their supporters in Parliament white camellias to wear in their buttonholes.

title: South Australia granted women right to vote
topic: suffrage, discrimination, racism
notes: ...accidentally also gave women the right to hold legislative office...Section 41 of Australian Constitution" "...excluded from women (and men) who were "aboriginal natives" of Australia, Africa, Asia, and the Pacific Islands, unless excepted under section 41 of the constitution...

title: The National Association of Colored Women (NACW)
topic: racism, discrimination
description: Their original intention was "to furnish evidence of the moral, mental and material progress made by people of color through the efforts of our women"." Now titled National Association of Colored Women's Clubs (NACWC)
notes: Made up of clubs / "also led efforts to improve education, and care for both children and the elderly

title: Fédération nationale Saint-Jean-Baptiste (FNSJB)
figures: Joséphine Marchand-Dandurand, Caroline Dessaulles-Béique, Marie Lacoste-Gérin-Lajoie, Marguerite Thibaudeau
topic: suffrage, equal rights, protection of women and children
description: Intended to "unite French Canadian Catholics in order to strengthen their action in the family and in society through union
notes: ...organized French- and English-speaking women often operated in what has been called “two solitudes” (that is, separate from one another and largely non-communicative)

title: Progressive Party (Bull Moose Party)
topic: suffrage
description: first national major political party to support women’s suffrage

title: Woman Suffrage Procession
topic: suffrage
description: First suffragist parade

title: 500,000 Signatures Petition Tour
topic: suffrage
description: Sara Bard Field, Frances Jolliffe, Mabel Vernon (organizing ahead of the others), Ingeborg Kinstedt, and Maria Kindberg tour the States with the petition, on the way to present it to President Woodrow Wilson in Washington D.C.

title: National Woman's Party (NWP)
topic: suffrage
description: Came from the Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage (initiated to assist the NAWSA Congressional Committee). Used militant methods from British suffragette movement.

title: First woman elected to the House of Representatives
topic: suffrage
description: Jeannette Rankin of Montana (still the only woman from Montana elected)

title: First International Women's Day
topic: suffrage, public affairs, political participation, discrimination
description: Started in Europe, majorly picked up by communist nations, and then by the second wave feminists

title: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom
topic: equal rights, peace, public affairs, women's rights
description: ...wished to end WWI and seek ways to ensure that no more wars took place." "...continues to be active in women's, peace and social justice issues
notes: 32 sections, 13 groups worldwide

title: Female enfranchisement in Canada
topic: suffrage, racism, discrimination
description: Black Canadians had to fight for slavery abolition under British rule (they were deemed property, not persons), Indigenous people only recieved full voting rights progressively from 1949/1969, and Asian Canadians weren't allowed to vote until after World War II. The Canadian Bill of Rights in 1960 helped to set a new, equal standard.
notes: After First World War ended

title: League of Women Voters
topic: suffrage, education
description: formed to help women take a larger role in public affairs after they won the right to vote

title: Persons Case
figures: Emily Murphy, Nellie McClung, Irene Parlby, Louise McKinney, Henrietta Muir Edwards
topic: political participation, public affairs, equal rights
description: Women gained right to sit on Senate of Canada after the British North America Act (1867) was used to determine that women are not "persons

title: Aba Women's Protest
topic: political participation, public affairs, direct taxation
description: Protests organized by rural women against the chiefs in order to demand back the rights taken from them under colonial rule.

title: Charter of United Nations signed
description: Went into force on 1945/10/24

title: Dublin Laundry Strike
topic: labor rights
description: Women working with laundry in Dublin went on strike for 14 weeks against the working conditions, low wages, overtime, and limited leave.

title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights
topic: equal rights, discrimination
description: States "their faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women
notes: translated into more than 500 languages

title: Canadian Voice of Women for Peace (VOW)
figures: Thérèse Casgrain, Grace Hartman, Ursula Franklin
topic: peace, social justice, education, disarmament
description: ...opposes violence and war and promotes nuclear disarmament, peace and social justice

title: Canadian Bill of Rights
topic: equal rights, suffrage, discrimination, gender equality, racism
description: It was the earliest expression of human rights law at the federal level in Canada, though an implied Bill of Rights had already been recognized in the Canadian Common Law.

title: Canadian Union of Public Employees (CUPE)
topic: equal rights, social justice, labor rights, equal pay
description: ...the largest union in Canada, representing some 700,000 workers in health care, education, municipalities, libraries, universities, social services, public utilities, transportation, emergency services and airlines. Over 60% of CUPE's members are women, and almost a third are part-time workers.

title: Fédération des femmes du Québec
figures: Thérèse Casgrain, Réjane Laberge-Colas, Monique Bégin
topic: equal rights, violence, discrimination, protection for women
description: ...a feminist organization binding individuals and groups in a common goal to "promote and defend the interests and the rights of women and to fight against all forms of violence, discrimination, marginalization and exclusion towards women"

title: Royal Commission on the Status of Women in Canada
figures: Lester B. Pearson, Laura Sabia, Florence Bird, Elsie MacGill, Lola M. Lange, Jeanne Lapointe, Doris Ogilvie, Jacques Henripin, John Peters Humphrey
topic: equal rights, equal pay, maternity leave, child care, birth control, reproductive rights, family law reform, education, labor rights, alimony, racism, discrimination
description: The commission’s mandate was to inquire into and report on the status of women in Canada, and to make specific recommendations to the federal government to ensure equality for women in all aspects of society.
notes: the first time a Royal Commission of inquiry had been chaired by a woman

title: Vancouver Women's Caucus (VWC)
topic: birth control, equal rights, education, reproductive rights
description: Feminist organization who were responsible for shutting down Parliament for the first time in Canadian history with their Abortion Caravan (a cross country protest opposing the 1969 amendments to the Criminal Code)

title: Front de libération des femmes du Québec (FLF)
topic: birth control, equal pay, housework enumeration, objectification, family unit redefinition
description: Feminist and nationalist association whose motto was "No liberation of Quebec without liberation of women, no liberation of women without liberation of Quebec!

title: National Action Committee on the Status of Women (NAC)
topic: poverty, racism, sexuality, gender equality, equal rights, violence, birth control, women's rights, education, public affairs, labor rights
description: founded "as a pressure group to lobby for the implementation of the 167 recommendations made in the Royal Commission on the Status of Women in Canada's 1970 report
notes: Dissolved due to funding problems, "A coalition of 22 groups when it originated under the name of the National Ad Hoc Committee on the Status of Women, the National Action Committee eventually grew into the largest national feminist organization with a total of 700 groups claiming affiliation

title: Canadian Abortion Rights Action League (CARAL)
figures: June Callwood, Kay Macpherson, Lorna Grant, Eleanor Wright Pelrine, Esther Greenglass, Henry Morgentaler
topic: abortion, contraception, birth control, women's rights, reproductive rights
description: ...a coalition of pro-choice activists, created in 1974, to protest the incarceration of Dr. Henry Morgentaler, who was jailed for providing safe, yet not legalized, abortions in Canada
notes: Was first Canadian Association for Repeal of the Abortion Law (CARAL), was replaced with Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada in 2005

title: Native Women’s Association of Canada (NWAC)
topic: equal rights, discrimination, labor rights, violence, women's rights, cultural preservation, gender equality, racism
description: founded on the collective goal to enhance, promote and foster the social, economic, cultural and political well-being of Indigenous women within their respective communities and Canada societies

title: Icelandic Women's Day Off
topic: labor rights, discrimination
description: Protesting wage discrepancy and unfair employment practices

title: Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) signed
topic: discrimination, violence, gender equality, public affairs, sexuality
description: International treaty/bill of rights, similar to International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination (ICERD)

title: Canadian Association for the Advancement of Women in Sport (CAAWS)
topic: equal rights, discrimination
description: ...goal was to see the enhanced presence of girls and women at all levels and in all areas – as athletes, participants, leaders, officials, coaches and trainers

title: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
topic: democratic rights, labor rights, equal rights, gender equality, language rights, discrimination, racism, cultural preservation, public affairs
description: ...guarantees certain political rights to Canadian citizens and civil rights of everyone in Canada from the policies and actions of all areas and levels of the government

title: Pauktuutit
topic: equal rights, discrimination, public affairs, violence, gender equality, protection of women and children, cultural preservation
description: to foster a greater awareness of the needs of Inuit women, and to encourage their participation in community, regional and national concerns in relation to social, cultural and economic development

title: Canada's first female governor general
topic: public affairs, equal rights
description: also Canada's first woman to be Speaker of the House of Commons
notes: Include explanation of what a governer general does

title: Women's Legal Education and Action Fund (LEAF)
topic: public affairs, discrimination, gender equality, sexuality, ableism, racism, birth control
description: To ensure the rights of women and girls in Canada, as guaranteed in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, are upheld in courts, human rights commissions and government agencies; and to take actions to reveal how factors such as race, class, Aboriginal status, sexual orientation, ability, and religion compound discrimination against women.

title: DisAbled Women's Network Canada (DAWN)
topic: poverty, exclusion, discrimination, violence, equal rights, public affairs, gender equality, ableism, racism
description: ...mission is "to end the poverty, isolation, discrimination and violence experienced by women with disabilities, and to fight for women with disabilities to have freedom of choice in all aspects of their lives."

title: National Organization of Immigrant and Visible Minority Women of Canada (NOIVMWC)
topic: gender equality, equal rights, discrimination, racism
description: focus on forming a united national voice to ensure equality for immigrant and visible minority women within bilingual Canada

title: Raging Grannies
country: CA, USA, AU, IE, IL, NZ, EN, SCT
topic: social justice, peace, discrimination, ageism, equal rights, environmentalism, violence, racism
description: social justice activists, all women old enough to be grandmothers, who dress up in clothes that mock stereotypes of older women, and sing songs at protests
notes: First called "Nuclear Emergency Response Team (NERT)

title: Inaugeration of National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women (White Ribbon Day)
topic: violence, women's rights, discrimination, equal rights, protection of women and children
description: It stands for awareness and change against the violence that occurs to women all around the world at the hands of men
notes: Happens on December 6, the anniversary of the 1989 École Polytechnique massacre

title: Declaration on the Elimination of Violence Against Women (DEVAW)
topic: equal rights, discrimination, violence

title: First Women's Memorial March
topic: violence, discrimination, women's rights, equal rights, protection of women and children, racism, class disparity
description: an annual event which occurs on February 14th in remembrance and in honour of the lives of missing and murdered indigenous women

title: Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993
topic: equal rights, labor rights, discrimination, protection of women and children, women's rights
description: Requires "covered employers to provide employees with job-protected and unpaid leave for qualified medical and family reasons.

title: Violence Against Women Act of 1994 (VAWA)
topic: violence, protection of women and children, public affairs, equal rights, women's rights
description: provided $1.6 billion toward investigation and prosecution of violent crimes against women, imposed automatic and mandatory restitution on those convicted, and allowed civil redress when prosecutors chose to not prosecute cases

title: First female Prime Minister of New Zealand
topic: political participation, public affairs

title: First V-Day
topic: violence, discrimination, women's rights, equal rights, protection of women and children, equal rights, human trafficking
description: a global activist movement to end violence against women and girls

title: United Nations Security Council Resolution 1325
topic: violence, women's rights
description: The first UN legal and political framework to recognize that war impacts women differently and to call for women’s participation in conflict prevention and resolution.

title: Equal Voice
figures: Rosemary Speirs, Donna Dasko, Libby Burnham, Christina McCall
topic: public affairs, political participation, equal rights, women's rights, labor rights
description: a national, bilingual, multi-partisan, non-governmental, non-profit organization that promotes the election of more women to all levels of Canadian politics

title: Women of Liberia Mass Action for Peace
figures: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, Leymah Gbowee, Crystal Roh Gawding, Comfort Freeman, Asatu Bah Kenneth
topic: peace, violence, women's rights
description: the women were able to achieve peace in Liberia after a 14-year civil war and later helped bring to power the country's first female head of state, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.

title: March for Women's Lives (2004)
topic: reproductive rights, abortion, education, sexual health, women's rights, birth control, protection of women and children, discrimination
description: to support the right to abortion, access to birth control, scientifically accurate sex education, and prevention and treatment of sexually transmitted infections, and to show public support for mothers and children

title: Abortion Rights Coalition of Canada (ARCC)
topic: reproductive rights, abortion, women's rights, birth control
description: Mission is "To ensure reproductive freedom by protecting and advancing rights and access to abortion and to quality reproductive health care.

title: Equality Act 2006
topic: discrimination, gender equality, equal rights, women's rights, ageism, ableism, racism, sexuality
description: ...requires public authorities "to promote equality of opportunity between women and men"

title: Gulabi Gang
topic: violence, women's rights
description: ...response to widespread domestic abuse and other violence against women...fights for the rights of women regardless of their caste.

title: Voices-Voix
topic: gender equality, human rights, women's rights, immigrant and refugee settlement rights, Indigenous rights, racism, discrimination, public affairs, environmentalism, free speech, transparency
description: ...a coalition of organizations and individuals seeking to defend democracy and enable civil society

title: First SlutWalk
topic: violence, discrimination, gender equality, human rights, women's rights, free speech, victim blaming, language reclaiming
description: ...a transnational movement calling for an end to rape culture, including victim blaming and slut shaming of sexual assault victims

title: Idle No More
figures: Nina Wilson, Sheelah Mclean, Sylvia McAdam Saysewahum, Jessica Gordon
topic: environmentalism, equal rights, human rights, Indigenous rights, discrimination, public affairs
description: generally opposes certain types of resource exploitation, particularly on First Nations territory

title: Tunisia 2014 Constitution (Article 21) states equal male and female rights
topic: equal rights, discrimination

title: A White Dress Doesn't Cover the Rape
description: Campaign against the Lebanese rape-marriage law Article 522 succeeds and the law is abolished.

title: Sulaliyyate women in Morocco gain equal land rights
topic: equal rights, land rights
